docs.lead_paragraph: Parishioners in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston say they plan to file a complaint of public fraud with the Massachusetts attorney general because they believe that millions of dollars collected over many years through special appeals for the priests' pension fund was used for other purposes. The parishioners, members of a group called the Council of Parishes, said they intended to file the complaint in the next few weeks as part of a package of legal actions involving the handling of money and other assets by the archdiocese. Some actions are civil lawsuits that have either already been filed or are to be filed soon, council members said.

headline.main: Parishioners in Boston Plan Suit Over Priests' Pensions

docs.snippet: Parishioners in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston say that millions of dollars collected for the priests' pension fund was used for other purposes.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration established an advisory panel to propose ways to rein in the growth of Medicaid, the insurance program for more than 50 million low-income people. By Sept. 1, the panel will recommend steps to save $10 billion over the next five years. By the end of 2006, it will propose long-term changes in the program. Michael O. Leavitt, the secretary of health and human services, will appoint up to 15 voting members of the commission, including current or former governors and state Medicaid directors. Eight members of Congress and up to 15 health policy experts will serve as nonvoting advisers. Robert Pear (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Medicaid Panel Appointed

docs.snippet: The Bush administration established an advisory panel to propose ways to rein in the growth of Medicaid, the insurance program for more than 50 million low-income people. By Sept. 1, the panel will recommend steps to save $10 billion over the next...

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials of the shuttered and financially troubled Cornerstone School in Jersey City said yesterday that they had a plan to allow it to reopen on Wednesday and finish the school year. But the school's ultimate fate would remain in question. Cornerstone, an 18-year-old private nonprofit school with 132 students in kindergarten through eighth grade, closed its doors on Monday because it lacked money to pay teachers and meet other expenses. Stephen Samborski, the school's interim chief executive, said the plan for the continuation of the school year was made possible by the intervention of the River School, a nearby profit-making private elementary school, which has agreed to pay teachers' salaries through the end of the year.

headline.main: Closed School In Jersey City Gets Reprieve, But at a Price

docs.snippet: Officials of the shuttered and financially troubled Cornerstone School in Jersey City said Friday that they had a plan to allow it to finish the school year.

docs.lead_paragraph: IT took only one semester for Dr. Jacques Chaoulli to flunk out of a Montreal law school a few years ago after he incessantly challenged professors in the classroom and in exams with his novel legal interpretations. But Dr. Chaoulli, a family physician, never lost his taste for legal argument, or his distaste for Canada's publicly financed health care system. He has taken what was once regarded as a nuisance case, challenging the constitutionality of the system all the way to the Supreme Court -- serving as his own lawyer, rolling his cardboard boxes stuffed with files into the chamber and paying for his efforts with a half million dollars out of his own pocket and that of his tolerant Japanese father-in-law.

headline.main: A Doctor-Lawyer-Gadfly v. Canada's Medical System

docs.snippet: Dr. Jacques Chaoulli has taken on Canada's publicly financed health care system, challenging its constitutionality all the way to the Supreme Court.

multimedia.credit: Dr. Jacques Chaoulli has challenged Canada's publicly financed medical system all the way to the Supreme Court.
multimedia.caption: Taking on Canada's Health Care

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Dr. Jacques Chaoulli has challenged Canada's publicly financed medical system all the way to the Supreme Court.

docs.lead_paragraph: The economy offered conflicting signs of growth yesterday. While a closely watched gauge of future business activity fell for the fourth consecutive month in April, job hunters got an encouraging indication when the number of new people signing up for unemployment insurance dropped sharply last week. The Conference Board said its composite index of leading economic indicators fell 0.2 percent last month, to 114.5. The decline was in line with what analysts had expected for the indicator, which is meant to forecast the economy's health over the coming three to six months.

headline.main: Economic Index Falls; So Do Jobless Claims

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr. vetoed a measure that would require Wal-Mart to increase spending for workers' health or pay more into a state health insurance fund. The bill, passed by the General Assembly, would require each company in the state with more than 10,000 employees -- only Wal-Mart meets that criteria -- to spend at least 8 percent of its payroll on health benefits or contribute more to the state's Medicaid program. Gary Gately (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Governor Vetoes Worker Benefits Bill

docs.lead_paragraph: SO, national nurses' week has come and gone and what happened? Nothing, despite estimates that by 2020 there will be 400,000 fewer nurses than are needed in this country. Drastic action is required. And here's the action I suggest: dethrone the surgeon general and appoint a National Nurse. Here's why. Prevention is the best way to lower health care costs. If people take care of themselves and don't get sickwell, you know the rest. And who better to educate Americans on how to take better care of themselves than nurses?
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Teri Mills says drastic action is required to address nursing shortage in United States; notes that estimates are that by 2020, there will be 400,000 fewer nurses than are needed; suggests appointment of a National Nurse who could highlight health care education through 15-minute weekly broadcasts to nation that would put emphasis on prevention; says National Nurse would give public recognition to valuable work that nurses perform, and hopefully would help stem nursing shortage by attracing people to the profession; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: It's time to dethrone the surgeon general and appoint a National Nurse.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department said on Wednesday that companies could give workers an additional 2.5 months to spend untaxed wages that they set aside in flexible spending arrangements for health care and child care expenses. The old rules required workers to spend the savings within a year or forfeit the unspent money. Under the new rules, if workers must now empty their accounts by the end of December, they could get until mid-March to spend the money, the agency said.

headline.main: Workers Given Extended Time For Spending

docs.abstract: Treasury Dept says that companies could give workers an additional 2.5 months to spend untaxed wages that they set aside in flexible spending arrangements for health care and child care expenses (M)
docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) - The Treasury Department said on Wednesday that companies could give workers an additional 2.5 months to spend untaxed wages that they set aside in flexible spending arrangements for health care and child care expenses.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Contrary to the implication of ''Life at the Top Isn't Just Better, It's Longer,'' it is not news that wealthier Americans get more and better health care than lower income people.

headline.main: A Portrait of Class in America

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Contrary to the implication of ''Life at the Top Isn't Just Better, It's Longer,'' it is not news that wealthier Americans get more and better health care than lower income people.

docs.lead_paragraph: The consuming Senate slugfest over judges (vital as they are) proves how Washington remains determined to fiddle while our biggest problem burns: a broken health care system that threatens working families and national competitiveness. President Bush -- who, with 51 percent of the vote, has set 100 percent of the agenda -- has taken a pass. And the terms of the debate remain surreal. After all, Margaret Thatcher would have been driven from office if she'd proposed anything as radically conservative as Bill Clinton's health plan, which would have left millions uncovered and had private doctors deliver the care.
docs.abstract: Matt Miller Op-Ed article points out that consuming Senate slugfest over judges proves how Washington remains determined to fiddle while biggest problem, broken health care system, burns; proposes that chief executives of corporations, which confront huge medical costs, make it their mission to put issue at center of 2008 campaign, engaging press and public by setting forth agenda for new health strategy (M)
docs.snippet: America's C.E.O.'s are the one group with the incentive and the clout to take on health care reform.
